definitions.text: a sudden and decisive increase
examples: a jump in attendance

definitions.text: an abrupt transition
examples: a successful leap from college to the major leagues

definitions.text: (film) an abrupt transition from one scene to another
a sudden involuntary movement
examples: he awoke with a start

definitions.text: descent with a parachute
examples: he had done a lot of parachuting in the army

definitions.text: the act of jumping; propelling yourself off the ground
examples: he advanced in a series of jumps
the jumping was unexpected

definitions.text: move forward by leaps and bounds
examples: The horse bounded across the meadow
The child leapt across the puddle
Can you jump over the fence?

definitions.text: move or jump suddenly, as if in surprise or alarm
examples: She startled when I walked into the room

definitions.text: make a sudden physical attack on
examples: The muggers jumped the woman in the fur coat

definitions.text: increase suddenly and significantly
examples: Prices jumped overnight

definitions.text: be highly noticeable
enter eagerly into
examples: He jumped into the game

definitions.text: rise in rank or status
examples: Her new novel jumped high on the bestseller list

definitions.text: jump down from an elevated point
examples: the parachutist didn't want to jump
every year, hundreds of people jump off the Golden Gate bridge
the widow leapt into the funeral pyre

definitions.text: run off or leave the rails
examples: the train derailed because a cow was standing on the tracks

definitions.text: jump from an airplane and descend with a parachute
cause to jump or leap
examples: the trainer jumped the tiger through the hoop

definitions.text: start (a car engine whose battery is dead) by connecting it to another car's battery
bypass
examples: He skipped a row in the text and so the sentence was incomprehensible

definitions.text: pass abruptly from one state or topic to another
examples: leap into fame
jump to a conclusion
jump from one thing to another

definitions.text: go back and forth; swing back and forth between two states or conditions
